title: 114_hr5956
content: The "Youth Opioid Use Treatment Help Act of 2016" or the "YOUTH Act" reauthorizes substance abuse treatment services for children and adolescents. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include young adults in substance use treatment programs, and a demonstration program for medication-assisted treatment for adolescents and young adults is established. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to eligible entities to establish demonstration programs for expanding access to medication-assisted treatment for opioid use disorders among adolescents and young adults, overcoming barriers to implementation, and providing resources for pediatric healthcare providers. Eligible entities include States, political subdivisions, Indian tribes, tribal organizations, and professional pediatric providers. To apply for a grant under this section, eligible entities must certify compliance with registration and licensing requirements and submit an application to the Director. Funding for a demonstration program can be received for up to 3 years, with annual reviews required for continued funding. The Director must review and approve funding for subsequent years of a program. Grant recipients must submit progress reports as required by the Director. The Director must submit a report to the Senate and House committees after all demonstration programs are completed. The curr_chunk discusses medication-assisted treatment availability for adolescents and young adults with opioid use disorders in the US, including barriers, demonstration programs, effectiveness evaluation, unintended consequences evaluation, and recommendations for accessibility. Definitions include individuals aged 10 to 26. The curr_chunk defines terms related to medication-assisted treatment for opioid use disorder in individuals aged 10 to 26, including pediatric health care providers and professional pediatric provider organizations. Authorization of Appropriations: $5,000,000 is authorized for this section. GAO will conduct a study and report on programs and research related to substance use and disorders among adolescents and young adults. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on how Federal agencies address prevention, treatment, and recovery from substance use and disorders among adolescents and young adults. The study will analyze research supported by the Federal Government on this topic, including any unique circumstances that may require specific treatment protocols for adolescents and young adults. The study will assess treatment protocols for substance use disorders in adolescents and young adults, focusing on research areas needing more investment. It will also evaluate Federal programs for prevention, treatment, and recovery effectiveness in this population. The study will assess gaps in Federal efforts related to prevention, treatment, and recovery from substance use disorders among adolescents and young adults. The Comptroller General will submit a report with findings and recommendations based on the study results within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General will provide recommendations for research, legislative, and administrative actions based on the study results on substance use disorders among adolescents and young adults.
